channel.title: Graham Rogers Blog
channel.description: Write an awesome description for your new site here. You can edit this line in _config.yml. It will appear in your document head meta (for Google search results) and in your feed.xml site description.

item.title: Code Snippets in Jekyll
item.description:
To start this off, this blog is based on Jekyll and I am learning the markdown syntax. And learning how to post code snippets of certain languages. This was created as a Ruby snippet with the template that Jekyll creates when you first build out the site…

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

by posting this in your markdown… 

{% highlight ruby %}
def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.
{% endhighlight %}

Now I guess I should explain that I just spent the last hour trying to figure out how to post that last code snippet and making it format with the liquid templating that jekyll uses. If you ever want to post about liquid templates you will have to surround the code in {% raw %} and {% endraw %} tags. AND THEN, I spent the next 30 minutes trying to find out how to properly escape an {% endraw %} which I’ll just point you to the two blog posts I found that helped me.

  • Escape Liquid template tags in Jekyll posts
  • Writing the endraw tag in Jekyll code blocks

How about some JavaScript highlighting? It’s easy using the built in support for Pygments and liquid templating, you can just post this bit of code in:

{% highlight js %}
var x = 'world';
function hello(args){
    console.log('Hello ' + args + '!');
};
{% endhighlight %}

and out pops this prettified code on the other end:

var x = 'world';
function hello(args){
    console.log('Hello ' + args + '!');
};

There are plenty of other languages that Pygments can highlight, so I suggest taking a look around on their documentation that I linked above.

item.title: My New Blog!
item.description:
Hi.

My name is Graham. I am starting this blog to start documenting anything I find relevant to my development learning process. Currently, my main interest for expanding my development skills are focused on NodeJS and AngularJS, and anything I find intriguing I tend to post here; Code snipets, other helpful posts from other blogs, anything and everything.

I am also a big proponent of open source technology, so anything I post on my blog, you should be able to recreate with (relative) ease, and hopefully if my experiences have helped even one person, I will be 100% happy.
